01.text: Here the writer begins a new part of the story in which Jesus spends 40 days in the wilderness, where Satan tempts him. In verse 4, Jesus rebukes Satan with a quotation from Deuteronomy.

01.ref: Jesus was led up by the Spirit
01.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Spirit led Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

01.ref: to be tempted by the devil
01.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "so the devil could tempt Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These refer to the same being. You may have to use the same word to translate both.

01.ref: he had fasted ... he was hungry

01.text: "40 days and 40 nights." This refers to 24-hour periods. AT: "40 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

01.ref: If you are the Son of God, command
01.text: It is best to assume that Satan knew that Jesus is the Son of God. Possible meanings are 1) this is a temptation to do miracles for Jesus' own benefit. AT: "You are the Son of God, so you can command" or 2) this is a challenge or accusation. AT: "Prove that you are the Son of God by commanding"
This is an important title that describes the relationship between the Jesus and God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This is an important title for Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

01.ref: command these stones to become bread
01.text: You could translate this with a direct quotation. AT: "say to these stones, 'Become bread!'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
Here "food" refers to food in general. AT: "food" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "Moses wrote this in the scriptures long ago" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

01.ref: Man shall not live on bread alone
01.text: This implies that there is something more important to life than food.

01.ref: but by every word that comes out of the mouth of God
01.text: Here "word" and "mouth" refer to what God says. AT: "but by listening to everything that God says" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

05.text: In verse 6, Satan quotes from the Psalms in order to tempt Jesus.

05.ref: If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down
05.text: It is best to assume that Satan knew that Jesus is the Son of God. Possible meanings are 1) this is a temptation to do a miracle for Jesus' own benefit. AT: "Since you are truly the Son of God, you can throw yourself down" or 2) this is a challenge or accusation. AT: "Prove that you are truly the Son of God by throwing yourself down" (UDB).
This is an important title that describes the relationship between God and Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"let yourself fall to the ground" or "jump down"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "for the writer wrote in the scriptures" or "for it says in the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

05.ref: He will command his angels to take care of you
05.text: "God will command his angels to take care of you." This can be translated with a direct quotation. AT: "God will say to his angels, 'Take care of him'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

07.text: In verse 7, Jesus rebukes Satan with another quotation from Deuteronomy.

It is understood that Jesus is quoting scripture again. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Again, I will tell you what Moses wrote in the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Here "you" refers to anyone. AT: "One should not test" or "No person should test"

07.ref: All these things I will give you
07.text: "I will give you all these things." The tempter is emphasizing here that he will give "all these things," not just some of them.

10.text: This is the end of the part of the story about how Satan tempted Jesus.
In verse 10, Jesus rebukes Satan with another quotation from Deuteronomy.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "For Moses also wrote in the scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the important new information that follows.

12.text: This is the beginning of a new part of the story in which the writer describes the beginning of Jesus' ministry in Galilee. These verses explain how Jesus came to be in Galilee. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Matthew starts to tell a new part of the story.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the king had arrested John" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

12.ref: in the territories of Zebulun and Naphtali
12.text: These are the names of the tribes that lived in these areas before foreigners took control of the land of Israel many years earlier. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

14.text: In verses 15 and 16, the writer quotes the prophet Isaiah to show that Jesus' ministry in Galilee was a fulfillment of prophecy.
This refers to Jesus going to live in Capernaum.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "what God said" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

14.ref: The land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali ... Galilee of the Gentiles!
14.text: All of these territories describe the same area. This can be translated as a complete sentence. AT: "In the territory of Zebulun and Naphtali ... in the territory of Galilee live many Gentiles!"
This is the Sea of Galilee.

14.ref: The people who sat in darkness have seen a great light
14.text: Here "darkness" refers to moral darkness or sin, which separates people from God. And, "light" refers to God's true message that saves people from their sin. This is the image of people who were without hope now having hope coming from God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

14.ref: to those who sat in the region and shadow of death, upon them has a light arisen
14.text: This basically has the same meaning as the first part of the sentence. Here "region and shadow of death" refers to spiritual death or a separation from God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

17.ref: Repent, for the kingdom of heaven has come near
17.text: The phrase "kingdom of heaven" refers to God ruling as king. This phrase is only in the book of Matthew. If possible, use the word "heaven" in your translation. AT: "our God in heaven will soon show himself to be king." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:mat:03:01|3:2]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

18.text: This begins a new scene within the part of the story about Jesus' ministry in Galilee. Here he begins to gather men to be his disciples.

18.ref: casting a net into the sea
18.text: The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. AT: "throwing a net into the water to catch fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Jesus invites Simon and Andrew to follow him, live with him, and become his disciples. AT: "Be my disciples"

18.ref: I will make you fishers of men
18.text: This metaphor means Simon and Andrew will teach people God's true message, so others will also follow Jesus. AT: "I will teach you to gather men to me like you used to gather fish" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

21.text: Jesus calls more men to be his disciples.
"Jesus called John and James." This phrase also means that Jesus invited them to follow him, live with him, and become his disciples.

21.ref: left the boat ... and followed him
21.text: It should be clear that this is a life change. These men are no longer going to be fishermen and are leaving the family business to follow Jesus for the rest of their lives.

23.text: This is the end of the part of the story about the beginning of Jesus' ministry in Galilee. These verses summarize what he did and how the people responded. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])
"teaching in the synagogues of the Galileans" or "teaching in the synagogues of those people"

23.ref: preaching the gospel of the kingdom
23.text: Here "kingdom" refers to God's reign as king. AT: "preaching the good news about how God will show himself as king" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

23.ref: every kind of disease and sickness
23.text: The words "disease" and "sickness" are closely related but should be translated as two different words if possible. "Disease" is what causes a person to be sick.
is the physical weakness or affliction that results from having a disease.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the demon-possessed" or "those whom demons control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"those who had seizures" or "those with diseases that caused them to have fits"
This name means "the Ten Towns" (UDB). This is the name of a region to the southeast of the Sea of Galilee. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
